Award.AwardTitle: REU Site: Research in Subtropical Biology At a Hispanic Gateway Institution
Award.AbstractNarration: This REU Site is situated at the University of Texas-Pan American (UTPA) which is located in the lower Rio Grande Valley in southern Texas. The REU program will support six undergraduates per year. Students in the program conduct year-long biological research under the supervision of their mentors, focusing on the local environment and organisms. The program runs slightly more than a year for each cohort. Students begin their research programs in mid-summer, continue them through the academic year, and complete them at the end of the following summer. During the regular academic year, students in each cohort: (1) take courses in Biological Writing, Biology Seminar, Statistics, Professional Ethics, and GRE preparation together; (2) attend professional development workshops; (3) participate in two on-site symposia (one in Fall and one in Spring), one regional conference, and one national conference, and; (4) attend presentations by visiting mentors and associated social events. Students' families are invited to attend social events with students, mentors, and visiting mentors, to help educate families about opportunities in scientific careers. During their second summer, students live on-campus to facilitate their research. The last months in the program overlap with the first months of the new students in the incoming cohort. This arrangement provides continuity between projects during transition between cohorts, and allows the veteran students to gain mentoring experience by assisting their peers entering the program. More information is available by visiting http://www.utpa.edu/programs/nsf/ or by contacting Zen Faulkes by emailing zfaulkes@utpa.edu (preferred) or phoning (956) 381-2614.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Research Experiences for Undergraduates program at The University of Texas-Pan American (UTPA REU) ran from 2007-2010. The program was designed to give undergraduate students a year-long research experience, as well as formal training in research ethics, technical writing, and oral presentations.

Twenty students participated in the program, in three cohorts of six students each. (Two students did not complete the program and were replaced part way through the year.) Fourteen of the UTPA REU students were Hispanic (an underrepresented group in science); four were Caucasian; two were Asian. Seventeen of the students were female.

Nineteen of the selected participants were from UTPA; one was an undergraduate at the University of Chicago. The low representation of students from outside the institution was due to the year-long nature of the program.

The goal of the UTPA REU programs was to prepare students to continue on to graduate school, and prepare them for research and technical careers. Of the twenty UTPA REU students,seven students are currently continuing their undergraduate studies; six are in, or have been accepted to, higher degree programs (five in graduate school, and one in medical school); three are employed in jobs related to biology; one is a K-12 teacher; and the current status of three are unknown.

REU students gave 23 presentations at regional conferences, 15 presentations at state conferences, and eight presentations at national conferences on their research.

One REU student published two papers based on her research in peer reviewed scientific journals. Both papers have already been cited by other authors in the scientific literature.
